name: Syphilitic Aortitis
description: A late manifestation of tertiary syphilis causing obliterative endarteritis of the vasa vasorum, leading to medial necrosis and aneurysmal dilation of the ascending aorta. Characterized by the classic 'tree-bark' appearance and coronary ostial stenosis.

mechanism.fibrosis: Replacement with scar tissue causing 'tree-bark' appearance

aortic_regurgitation.mechanism: Dilation of aortic root widens commissures

coronary_ostial_stenosis.unique: Unlike atherosclerosis, starts at ostium not downstream

aortic_arch_involvement.aneurysm: May compress trachea, esophagus, recurrent laryngeal nerve

classic_signs: Signs of tertiary syphilis (Argyll Robertson pupils, tabes dorsalis)

serologic_testing.interpretation: Both should be positive in late syphilis

imaging.characteristic: Linear calcification of ascending aorta on CXR

pathology.gross: Tree-bark or wrinkled appearance of intima
pathology.microscopic: Perivascular plasma cell infiltration, vasa vasorum endarteritis
pathology.histologic_triad: Medial necrosis + intimal wrinkling + adventitial scarring

antibiotic_treatment.regimen: Penicillin G - late latent syphilis protocol
antibiotic_treatment.benzathine_penicillin: 2.4 million units IM weekly x 3 weeks
antibiotic_treatment.note: Antibiotics halt progression but do not reverse damage

clinical_pearls: Tree-bark appearance of ascending aorta is pathognomonic
Coronary ostial stenosis is UNIQUE to syphilitic aortitis - starts at ostium
Ascending aorta most affected because it has most vasa vasorum
Latency period 15-30 years - now rare due to penicillin treatment of primary syphilis
learning_objectives: Describe the pathophysiology of syphilitic aortitis and vasa vasorum involvement
Identify the unique pattern of coronary ostial stenosis in syphilitic aortitis
Outline diagnostic and management strategies for cardiovascular syphilis

sources.source: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st ed. McGraw-Hill.
